item.title: Curvature of Curves
item.description: If we agree that lines have no curvature and circles have constant curvature then we’re more or less forced to say that curvature of a circle should be inversely proportional to the radius, after all a line is a circle with an infinite radius. We might as well Define the curvature \(\kappa\) at every point of a circle of radius \(r\) to be \(1/r\) .

item.title: What's the deal with Curvature?
item.description: A curved curve from Curveland When we think of curves we naturally think of them as having some kind of a curvature. A circle is curved but a line is not. Similarly for surfaces, a sphere is curved (and so is a cylinder) but a plane is not. But, there is a subtle difference between the curvature of curves and surfaces. It is possible to take a string and form a circle out of it without stretching or compressing, but it is not possible to take a flat piece of paper and shape it into a sphere (but you can into a cylinder) without stretching or compressing.
